ygData.msgSnippet: Stoichiometric coefficients must be integers.  For the reaction you cite, specify it as 2 CH4 + 3 O2 = 2 CO + 4 H2O Then cut the pre-exponential term in the

Stoichiometric coefficients must be integers.  For the reaction you 
cite, specify it as

2 CH4 + 3 O2 => 2 CO + 4 H2O

Then cut the pre-exponential term in the rate expression by two, since 
as written here this reaction consumes two CH4, instead of 1, as 
originally written.  Since you are specifying the reaction orders for 
the reactants, the stoichiometric coefficients will not be used in 
computing the reaction rate of progress, only in converting from rate 
of progress to species production rates.

Cantera requires integer stoichiometric coefficients since this allows 
using some faster numerical algorithms and there is no loss of 
generality, since every balanced reaction can be written with integer 
stoichiometric coefficients.  In particular, species production rates 
are computed from the reaction rates of progress using integer addition 
operations, instead of floating-point multiplies. Also, except when a 
reaction order is explicitly specified (as in this reaction), rates of 
progress are computed using integer multiply operations, instead of 
floating-point exponentiation.   All of this turns out to make a big 
difference in the performance using large mechanisms, and is one main 
reason that flame calculations, for example, are often faster with 
Cantera than with "other well-known software packages."  (There are 
other reasons, too.)

Dave



On Jul 6, 2004, at 7:32 AM, kvirgilm wrote:

> I am trying to implement a 'global' mechanism for the gas phase 
> reactions.
> I am specifying the reactions as such in the cti file:
>
> reaction( " CH4 + 1.5 O2 => CO + 2 H2O ", [5.3044e8, 0.1902, 13940.0], 
> order
> = "CH4:0.587917 O2:0.620861")
>
> When I go to convert it to xml, I get the error:
>
> cti2ctml methane-3step.cti
> Traceback (most recent call last):
>   File "./.cttmp.py", line 7, in ?
>     execfile(file)
>   File "./methane-3step.cti", line 98, in ?
>     reaction( " CH4 + 1.5 O2 => CO + 2 H2O ", [5.3044e8, 0.1902, 
> 13940.0],
> order = "CH4:0.587917 O2:0.620861")
>   File "/usr/lib/python2.2/site-packages/ctml_writer.py", line 643, in 
> __init__
>     self._r = getReactionSpecies(r)
>   File "/usr/lib/python2.2/site-packages/ctml_writer.py", line 323, in
> getReactionSpecies
>     n = int(t)
> ValueError: invalid literal for int(): 1.5
>
>
> Is there a simple fix to allow for non-integer stoichiometric 
> coefficients?  I
> can manually enter these into the xml file, but then the c++ code 
> crashes
> when it tries to import the gas-phase mechanism.
